importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the arrest and the incident at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, marking a critical moment when a potential mass shooting was prevented.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which Cagle arrived at the airport and was observed near the TSA security checkpoint, indicating the timing of the threat and interception.

keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, planned to shoot up Atlanta’s busiest airport via a social media livestream.
Cagle was reportedly streaming on social media with the intent to 'shoot it up' at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport.
Police intercepted him at the airport after receiving a tip from his family who reported his online threats and possession of an assault rifle.
An AR-15 assault rifle with 27 rounds of ammunition was discovered in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal.
Cagle was arrested after entering the airport and approaching the TSA checkpoint, where officers recognized him from a photo provided by family members.
He was charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
Cagle has a history of mental health struggles, including schizophrenia, and previously told friends he was on medication.
The case highlights the role of community vigilance and social media awareness in preventing active threats.
Federal authorities are investigating how Cagle legally obtained the firearm, as he is a convicted felon and not legally permitted to possess a gun.
The incident was averted due to timely intervention by family members and law enforcement coordination.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 49-year-old man from Cartersville, Georgia, named Billy Joe Cagle, a convicted felon with a history of mental health struggles including schizophrenia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family reported that he had streamed on social media a plan to 'shoot it up' at the airport. Officers found an AR-15 assault rifle with 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle had entered the airport and approached the TSA checkpoint, where he was intercepted by police who recognized him from a photo provided by family members. He was charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon. The incident was averted due to timely reporting by family members, highlighting the importance of community vigilance and social media monitoring in preventing mass violence.
